reviewText: another great classic from 3 time oscar-winner, William Wyler. this time it's a provacative and risque film at the time of its release (1952). based on the Theodore Dreiser novel 'Sister Carrie' this film tells the story of a tragic romance between a wealthy but married restauranteur and common lower-class working girl. the film never attempts to glorify or even condone on any level the actions portrayed by the principle actors. instead, the film merely suggests the inevitable tragedies that could befall such behavior between consenting adults. however, it never really condemns or condones, it jusr simply tells a tragic story. a must see.as for the DVD, some artifacts are present but overall the transfer is good and the sound is also good for a film of this age.

reviewText: Someone on here wrote that this is a great look into the time period in which this movie is set; perhaps it is, perhaps it is not.  It seems to be a mix of a cinematic story line and reality during the time period in which it is set, pre-automobiles.  I have not read the book this movie is supposedly based on, so I cannot compare the book and the movie.Here are my thoughts on the movie: it is depressing.  I waited for some sign that the screen writer would somehow change the course of the movie and show humanity in a better light.  It never did - the jilted soon to be ex-wife of Olivier's character is a good example; her selfish desire to totally destroy her husband was eventually realized.  The transition of Jennifer Jones' character from a dependent, insecure country girl to a successful performer is not explained (portrayed) well, if at all.  The viewer gains no meaningful insight into what it must have cost the shy woman to go from bashful country bumpkin to highly "sophisticated" and admired performer.  The struggle of Laurence Olivier's character is better portrayed, probably mostly because of the skills of Mr. Olivier.  Yet the path of his character's decent into poverty and doom is not dealt with much, either.  This would have been a much better movie had the transitions of the character's success (Jones' character) and demise (Olivier's character) been developed more; the success of one and demise of the other are the obvious overall themes of the movie and deserved more from the director.Everything considered, I did not like the movie much; at times I gave it two stars (did not like it) and, at other times, three stars (it was barely OK).  Toward the end, my mind ended up with a "did not like it," thus, only two stars.
summary: Depressing, lacking depth in certain parts...

reviewText: Amazon Prime should be congratulated for having this movie in their selection; it is very well directed and superbly acted and follows Theodore Dreiser's novel "Sister Carrie" quite well.  I watched it to help me write a paper on this novel, which shows how our consumer society, by making people aware of their unsatisfied desires and channelling those desires into the pursuit of consumer goods, demoralizes the human spirit.  I recommend it to any student of American Literature or history.
summary: Carrie, the 1952 movie based on Dreiser's novel Sister Carrie

reviewText: This was lovely understated film by the great director William Wyler with a touching performance by Laurence Olivier and a truly memorable one by Jennifer Jones.  I was thrilled to see it come to DVD, the only problem being that the print used is unrestored and only so-so in quality.  In some scenes the striking black-and-white photography looks good, but in other scenes the contrast is cloudy and inconsistent.  There are even a couple of shots that are marred by scratches.  It's not that it's bad really -- if you can get this for a good price, buy it -- it's just that the quality is not very good.  What would have been great for VHS looks below par on DVD. This film needed to be restored.

reviewText: Jennifer Jones thrillingly brings to life Theodore Dreiser's "Sister Carrie" in the celebrated film version, CARRIE.  Set in Chicago at the turn of the century, the story concerns unhappily married restaurant owner George Hurstwood (Laurence Olivier) who becomes entranced by newcomer Carrie Meeber (Jones).  George risks everything in order to have a relationship with the beautiful girl who eventually brings about his ruin.  Jones and Olivier give superlative performances in the lead roles.  Olivier especially breaks my heart with his portrayal of Hurstwood.  This is in my opinion Olivier's greatest film role.Director William Wyler injects the film with a haunting dark beauty and melancholy, which is enhanced by David Raksin's accomplished score.  With Eddie Albert, Miriam Hopkins, Sara Berner and Ray Teal.  This new DVD from Paramount restores a scene which was cut prior to the film's original American theatrical release.
summary: Laurence Olivier in his greatest film performance
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a very good representation of the book.  Carrie's initial experience in Chicago, the attitude of her sister and brother-in-law, her meeting the two important men in her life, and her eventual success on her own were all portrayed in a cogent and believable manner.  Some of the story was whitewashed . . but that didn't take away from the movie.  It's hard not to feel compassion for the major figures in the story, and it is a story that is probably repeated over and over again . . giving up everything for the love of a woman.
summary: For the Love of a Woman!

reviewText: This was a pretty powerful melodrama, thanks to the great performance of Sir Laurence Olivier.Olivier plays an unhappily-married older man who falls for the young and beautiful Jennifer Jones (not hard to understand!).....and pays a huge price for his adultery. Olivier is near-mesmerizing in this film and Jones is absolutely gorgeous. Eddie Albert was a bit annoying (but effective) in his role and Miriam Hopkins is downright brutal in her small part as Olivier's wife.The shocking thing about this film was the subject matter, rare for its day. It was ahead of its day in one respect: it makes the adulterers into the sympathetic "good guys." I'm surprised that got by the censors of the day. Jones' character is oddly innocent for someone "shacking up" with Albert.This was highly involving, a tough story to put down once it started. Note: One of the scenes near the end of the story - the flophouse scene - was inserted on the DVD. It had previously been cut out of the theatrical release.
summary: Olivier Elevates This Solid Soaper Big-Time

reviewText: Anyone interested in acting should watch Olivier's performance as George Hurstwood in Carrie.It is a wonder of observation, sensitivity, restraint and daring. The great director Elia Kazan, who lived across the street from Olivier when he was preparing to play Hurstwood, spoke of watching Olivier rehearsing on his own, determining the right way to enact the small gesture of pulling a chair back from a table in order to seat someone. Olivier tried it looking at the chair, looking at the floor, he tried it slowly, abruptly, and on and on. Kazan's point was that Olivier put tremendous thought and care into what most actor's would regard as an insignificant piece of business. That thought and care show in his every word and gesture.This is the third of William Wyler's best films, the others being Wuthering Heights and The Heiress.

reviewText: I wasn't expecting such a dark and depressing movie when I bought this.  Starring Lawrence Olivier, one would expect his representation of a successful entrepreneurial American George Hurstwood would brighten the film in every aspects.  Indeed he is.  He is a wealthy restaurant co-owner, forgoing all his wealth and estate, divorcing his wife for just one country girl Carrie (Jennifer Jones) and began his miserable story.  The story itself is well developed, with every moment of highs and lows well positioned to catch the audience hearts and minds.  In the end, although the dignity of George Hurstwood is kept until the end of the movie, the audience would be saddened by the fact that George could not return back to his golden age, even his love of Carrie is so intense and their love might be so compelling.  A general indication of the hard economic times they were in, I suppose.  Overall, a good movie shot in the '50s with a touch of realism current, but not for those who are light-hearted and looking for a happy-ending love story.
summary: Dramatic, dark and depressing romance movie

reviewText: I am a huge Jennifer Jones fan, and that is why I own this movie. (I love classic movies, but Laurence Olivier is not someone I follow, before anyone who is a fan gets mad at me for this review!) For someone who only made about 25 movies, it is incredible how Jennifer Jones always managed to get such high-quality pictures. The only one I did not like, which appeared to be low-quality, was "Indiscretion of an American Wife." (There are about 5 movies I have not yet seen.)This movie... how could she possibly choose Olivier over Eddie Albert?? Now, this is saying nothing about his acting ability, which in this role was superb. But he smiled perhaps twice in the entire movie, and Eddie was just so cheerful. He was very direct in his interest in Jones's character. For that day and age, I can see how that would make a woman uncomfortable. He didn't give her much of a chance to say no. But to me, she didn't seem to be too happy when she was with either of them. It still made for a very interesting story though. It is by no means my favorite Jennifer Jones movie. That goes toPortrait of Jennie,Love Letters [VHS], andThe Towering Inferno (Special Edition)... just to start.*SLIGHT SPOILER* We feel so bad for Olivier's character because he is so disheveled and looks like a bum, because he has lost his money. Jones's character is horrified. It is awful. But does he really look so bad? By today's standards? His face looks exactly like half of all men who go out in public: scruffy and unshaven. And his clothes are BETTER! Today guys wear jeans and t-shirts. If we are lucky, their jeans are covering their butt-crack. THAT is horrifying, I think. I know, this has nothing to do with the movie, which had a pretty important theme. But I do find it kind of sad that the lower-class of the past was better-dressed than the middle-class of today. You can see it in pretty much any old movie.(It is also too bad they did not keep the title "Sister Carrie." The horror story has taken over the title "Carrie.")

reviewText: Based on Theodore Dreiser's novel, Sister Carrie. Jennifer Jones plays Carrie Meeber, a young woman who moves to Chicago to better herself. Carrie learns the facts of life, that the big city is filled with selfish people. She goes through two lovers, a young Eddie Albert and an older man whom she ruins. Laurence Olivier plays Hurstwood, the man who risks all to recapture his youth. Carrie loves the attention, and Hurstwood has his moment. My favorite scene is where he gives her a new hat. The relationship runs its course. Carrie becomes an actress, and Hurstwood hits the skids. Dreiser's prose is clumsy.

reviewText: *** A bit of a spoiler, the package makes this look like a glossy romance, and it is much deeper and darker.***This movie really should have been called "George,"as it is the story of a man (Laurence Oliver) who ruins his life for love.  Olivier is essentially different here, a humble man who suffers silently, simply wonderful, and shows here in his youth moments of the great acting of his last years (important, because he was aged up for this role).  It is a simply brilliant film for him.Jennifer Jones, playing Carrie, also gives one of her best performances, and their chemistry is fantastic.  She was in her 30s and still looks 18, which helps a film where she ages from about 18 to 36.I did not know anything of this "girl comes to the big city, gets compromised, and rises above" story.  It is far more than this trite outline.  This wonderful script dips and turns with the complexities of life relationships, legal relationships, and the things we don't tell each other.Miriam Hopkins, even in her perky youth, was always rather arch and tart.  This is used to fantastic advantage here in a very dislikable role.  Eddie Albert is also used to best advantage as a flirty traveling salesman and lady killer.In black and white, the story is about the divisions of poverty and wealth, and how life can take us through levels.  Edith Head's magnificent costuming takes the leads from highs to lows, tenements to townhouses to the glamour of the stage in the early 1900s.The score is by David Raksin, who did such memorable scores as WHIRLPOOL, THE BIG COMBO, FALLEN ANGEL, and PAT AND MIKE.  While heavy handed by today's standards, it is musically complex and eloquent, and truly augments the emotional journey of the action.  It is some of the best of it's time, evocative of the dissonant soundtracks of ON THE WATERFRONT, and REBEL WITHOUT A CAUSE.The realeased film had a section removed set in poverty row/homeless men's housing.  This section has been restored on the DVD, which reinstates yet another level of complexity, the mixture of poverty, humiliation and pride.All this makes this film wrenching, memorable and complete.  Do not miss this one, it is highly regarded for all the right reasons.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Movie: *****  DVD Quality: ***  DVD Extras: N/AA tour de force performance by Laurence Olivier distinguishes this screen adaptation of Theodore Dreiser's novel "Sister Carrie". Under William Wyler's sure-handed direction, Olivier portrays a middle aged man whose comfortable, but unhappy, life tragically unravels when he persues the love of a young woman in a desperate last attempt at personal happiness. Sabotaged by fate, circumstance, and his own compromised morality, Olivier's descent into poverty, isolation, and despair is harrowing to witness. As the object of his passion, Jennifer Jones is very good indeed in the title role. Certainly, she has never appeared more lovely than she does in this film; it is critical that the audience believe that Olivier's character would risk everything for her, and sure enough, one can easily understand why Olivier is captivated by her charm and grace.  Equally effective in key supporting roles are Miriam Hopkins in the role of Olivier's controlling shrew of a wife and Eddie Albert as a smooth-talking salesman who also loves Jones in his own opportunistic way.The Paramount DVD edition of this neglected jewel is a mixed bag quality-wise.  On the one hand, it includes a long-censored and important sequence showing Olivier's character at his lowest, sick and disheveled and destitute, spending the night in a filthy flophouse.  On the other hand, the transfer quality is uniformly substandard, featuring gainy video that is sometimes plagued by vertical lines running through the picture, and often muddy audio.  Regrettably, the DVD does not include any extras whatsoever, not even a package insert with liner notes. Despite these annoying flaws and omissions, this DVD is still very much worth a look just to see one of the greatest actors of the 20th century in what arguably may be his finest screen performance.

Sadly, the players with the shallowest depth of humanity, Mrs. Hurstwood and confidence scam man Charles Druet, are least damaged by their ruination of the main characters.An entertaining review may be found here:[...]

reviewText: First of all, be warned - this is a downer and not a film to be recommended to anyone who is suffering from depression or low self esteem.Theodore Dreiser's novel, "Sister Carrie," first published in 1900, had its share of controversy and initial sales were poor. Today it is viewed as a major American classic. Dreiser's characters are victims of chance and circumstance and their motivations are fueled by their desires without serious thought to the consequences of their actions. Readers were especially shocked that the heroine's "sinful" ways would be rewarded in the end."Carrie" was filmed in 1950 but it sat on the shelf for two years before being released in 1952. The studio felt that the political climate at the time wasn't right for the film. In fact, this dvd version contains a scene that wasn't included in the American release but was in prints for the foreign markets. A note at the beginning of the film alludes to the politics of the time but really it just raises more questions than answers. This is a film begging for a commentary but unfortunately there isn't one.With no extras provided, we only have the film to enjoy but what an excellent film this is. The technical aspects are top notch with William Wyler's skillful direction making this one of his best films, Victor Milner's sharp and unsentimental black and white photography and David Raskin's lovely score. But what really shines are the actors. Jennifer Jones, certainly one of the most beautiful actresses to ever work in Hollywood, is perfect as Carrie - naive and innocent in the beginning but learning the ways of the world too late, Eddie Albert as the charming but oily Drouet and Miriam Hopkins as the icy and shrewd Julia Hurstwood. The stand out performance, however, has to be Laurence Olivier, as George Hurstwood, the man whose obsession for Carrie eventually leads to his downfall. This is arguably his best screen performance but one that is often overlooked."Carrie" is a mature and sensitive film and one that makes a stark contrast to Hollywood's usual romantised fare. It is an unfogettable film but certainly not for everyone.
summary: Excellent adaptation of the Dreiser classic

reviewText: Jennifer Jones stars as a innocent Mid-Western girl (fresh from the farm) that travels to Chicago to live with her older sister's family. The time period is the 1890s.She is beautiful and elegant despite her rustic fashion; plain white high necked blouse and drab skirt, as she tries to succeed in various factory jobs that are much too rigorous for her.  She meets up with Charlie Druea (Eddie Albert) who is a salesman on the make, though very much taken with her beauty and shy allure.  He invites her to move into his apartment, after her sister disapproves of her taking money from him after losing her job in a shoe factory. They set up housekeeping together.  In the neighborhood is Fitzgerald’s Restaurant, which caters to an elite clientele.  The restaurant is managed by George Hearstwood (Laurence Olivier), a gentleman in every way, although married to a social climbing, evil spouse, (Miriam Hopkins).Carrie and Charlie dine at Fitzgerald's shortly after Carrie moves in with Charlie. She is very taken with George Hearstwood because he possesses all the qualities she is looking for in a man; someone with class and dignity, who knows how to treat a woman. Charlie invites George to take Carrie to the theater when he goes out of town on a sales trip.Carrie is soon in love with George and they end up running away to New York City together although he hasn't the nerve to tell Carrie he cannot obtain a divorce from his wife and has a large sum of money on his person from Fitzgerald's.The remainder of the film shows the demise of George. He has paid back the money he owed Fitzgerald but the rumors of his thievery have travelled as far as New York. He is doomed to failure in every attempt he makes to succeed.Ashamed of his status as a failure, he leaves Carrie alone in their shabby little flat. But Carrie does not give up or go back to her parent's farm.  She tries out for a theatrical production bit part and we see her ascending the ladder to fame and fortune, with her name and photograph on the Theater Marquees. Now she is more beautiful than ever, in her velvet and fur trimmed dresses and hats.George finds his way back to her at the stage door one evening, but only to ask for a small handout to eat something in order to survive.Carrie wants him to stay with her and leaves him momentarily to run across the street to an open all night bistro for food.But George is gone, fading back into shadows, and most likely meeting his end....They were ill fated lovers....right for each other? Alas, they met at the wrong time...and as Carrie says in one of her earlier scenes with George,  "I should have met you sooner, but I didn't, and now I'm not free."Carrie will never be free herself...for she will regret having ruined George's life. A tragedy indeed....
Title: N/A
